title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO (AP) — In a game defined by a singular, supernova performance, Hakeem Olajuwon did not merely lead his team to victory; he authored a masterpiece. The Houston Rockets defeated the San Antonio Spurs 103-99, but the final score is merely a footnote to the historic 48-point, 21-rebound clinic put on by "The Dream."

From the opening tip, Olajuwon was an unstoppable force, operating with a devastating blend of power and finesse. The Spurs, despite a valiant 25-point effort from Vinny Del Negro and a strong 18-point, 10-rebound double-double from Tim Duncan, had no answer. Every double-team was spun through, every contest at the rim was met with a soft touch or a powerful finish. Olajuwon wasn't just scoring; he was dominating the glass, hauling in 21 rebounds to completely control the paint on both ends of the floor.

While Olajuwon’s supporting cast played their roles to perfection—with Clyde Drexler distributing 8 assists and Charles Barkley adding 9 points—this night belonged to one man. The game was tight, a tense Western Conference battle, but every time the Spurs threatened, Olajuwon had a response. A baseline fadeaway. An offensive putback. A thunderous dunk.

In the end, the Spurs were simply witnesses to history. On this night in 1997, Hakeem Olajuwon delivered one of the most dominant individual performances of his legendary career, carrying the Rockets on his broad shoulders and reminding the basketball world of his unparalleled greatness.
